articles.headline: Pension Deal Closer, but Hurdles Exist
articles.snippet: Congressional negotiators have reached a preliminary oral agreement on a long-awaited package of amendments to overhaul the nation’s pension system.
articles.abstract: Congressional negotiators have reached a preliminary oral agreement on a long-awaited package of amendments to overhaul the nation’s pension system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congressional negotiators have reached a preliminary oral agreement on a long-awaited package of amendments to overhaul the nation’s pension system, the chairman of the negotiating group said yesterday.

articles.headline: Fed Chief Optimistic on Inflation
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke expressed optimism that the central bank’s heavy lifting to fend off inflation may be almost finished.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke expressed optimism that the central bank’s heavy lifting to fend off inflation may be almost finished.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 19 — Despite the recent acceleration in consumer prices, pushed higher largely by oil prices, the chairman of the Federal Reserve expressed optimism on Wednesday that the central bank’s heavy lifting to fend off inflation may be almost finished.

articles.headline: Reluctantly Adjusting to Oil Cost
articles.snippet: Demand is strong at energy-dependent operations, which are raising prices to recapture as much as they can of the run-up in oil.
articles.abstract: Demand is strong at energy-dependent operations, which are raising prices to recapture as much as they can of the run-up in oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every Monday morning Dean England, chief executive of a family-owned trucking company, logs onto the Energy Department’s Web site and checks the latest average cost of a gallon of diesel fuel. If it is up enough, he raises the charge to haul produce across the country in his tractor-trailers.

articles.headline: Judge Gives Wal-Mart Reprieve on Benefits
articles.snippet: The decision was a major blow to state efforts to force employers to provide more generous health benefits.
articles.abstract: The decision was a major blow to state efforts to force employers to provide more generous health benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a setback to state efforts to force employers to provide more generous health benefits, a federal judge yesterday struck down a Maryland law that was aimed at the nation’s largest retailer, Wal-Mart Stores.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Like Having a Secretary in Your PC
articles.snippet: If you’re among the thousands who have abandoned dictation software in the past, it’s now ready for prime time.
articles.abstract: If you’re among the thousands who have abandoned dictation software in the past, it’s now ready for prime time.
articles.lead_paragraph: TESTING, testing, one two three. Is this thing on?

articles.headline: Toll Rises in Middle East; Bunker Is Hit
articles.snippet: The deadliest day yet in the deepening two-front Middle East crisis claimed more than 70 lives in Lebanon, the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and northern Israel, with no immediate cease-fire in sight.
articles.abstract: The deadliest day yet in the deepening two-front Middle East crisis claimed more than 70 lives in Lebanon, the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and northern Israel, with no immediate cease-fire in sight.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Iraqi Prime Minister Denounces Israel’s Actions
articles.snippet: The denunciation was a sharp break with the U.S. position and was noticeably stronger than those made by Sunni Arab governments.
articles.abstract: The denunciation was a sharp break with the U.S. position and was noticeably stronger than those made by Sunni Arab governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 19 — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq on Wednesday forcefully denounced the Israeli attacks on Lebanon, marking a sharp break with President Bush’s position and highlighting the growing power of a Shiite Muslim identity across the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Michael Slackman

articles.headline: Pension Deal Closer, but Hurdles Exist
articles.snippet: Congressional negotiators have reached a preliminary oral agreement on a long-awaited package of amendments to overhaul the nation's pension system, the chairman of the negotiating group said yesterday.     The chairman, Senator Michael B. Enzi, R...
articles.abstract: Congressional negotiators have reached a preliminary oral agreement on a long-awaited package of amendments to overhaul the nation's pension system, the chairman of the negotiating group said yesterday.     The chairman, Senator Michael B. Enzi, Republican of Wyoming, left a session yesterday afternoon saying that he thought ''everything is resolved, pending getting the exact wording.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Congressional negotiators have reached a preliminary oral agreement on a long-awaited package of amendments to overhaul the nation's pension system, the chairman of the negotiating group said yesterday.

articles.headline: Fed Chief Optimistic on Inflation
articles.snippet: Despite the recent acceleration in consumer prices, pushed higher largely by oil prices, the chairman of the Federal Reserve expressed optimism on Wednesday that the central bank's heavy lifting to fend off inflation may be almost finished.     ''...
articles.abstract: Despite the recent acceleration in consumer prices, pushed higher largely by oil prices, the chairman of the Federal Reserve expressed optimism on Wednesday that the central bank's heavy lifting to fend off inflation may be almost finished.     ''The economy appears to be in a period of transition,'' Ben S. Bernanke, the Fed chairman, said at a hearing of the Senate Banking Committee. The outlook, he said, is for somewhat slower economic growth, a slight increase in unemployment and a broad-based cooling of the nation's housing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 19 - Despite the recent acceleration in consumer prices, pushed higher largely by oil prices, the chairman of the Federal Reserve expressed optimism on Wednesday that the central bank's heavy lifting to fend off inflation may be almost finished.

articles.headline: Judge Gives Wal-Mart Reprieve on Benefits
articles.snippet: In a setback to state efforts to force employers to provide more generous health benefits, a federal judge yesterday struck down a Maryland law that was aimed at the nation's largest retailer, Wal-Mart Stores.     The judge ruled that the federal ...
articles.abstract: In a setback to state efforts to force employers to provide more generous health benefits, a federal judge yesterday struck down a Maryland law that was aimed at the nation's largest retailer, Wal-Mart Stores.     The judge ruled that the federal law governing employer-provided health benefits takes precedence over the state law, which would have required companies with 10,000 or more workers to spend at least 8 percent of their payrolls on health insurance, or pay the difference into a state Medicaid fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a setback to state efforts to force employers to provide more generous health benefits, a federal judge yesterday struck down a Maryland law that was aimed at the nation's largest retailer, Wal-Mart Stores.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Iraqi Prime Minister Denounces Israels Actions
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq on Wednesday forcefully denounced the Israeli attacks on Lebanon, marking a sharp break with President Bush's position and highlighting the growing power of a Shiite Muslim identity across the Middle Eas...
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq on Wednesday forcefully denounced the Israeli attacks on Lebanon, marking a sharp break with President Bush's position and highlighting the growing power of a Shiite Muslim identity across the Middle East.     ''The Israeli attacks and airstrikes are completely destroying Lebanon's infrastructure,'' Mr. Maliki said at an afternoon news conference inside the fortified Green Zone, which houses the American Embassy and the seat of the Iraqi government. ''I condemn these aggressions and call on the Arab League foreign ministers' meeting in Cairo to take quick action to stop these aggressions. We call on the world to take quick stands to stop the Israeli aggression.''
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 19 - Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq on Wednesday forcefully denounced the Israeli attacks on Lebanon, marking a sharp break with President Bush's position and highlighting the growing power of a Shiite Muslim identity across the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Michael Slackman

articles.headline: Reluctantly Adjusting to Oil Cost
articles.snippet: Every Monday morning Dean England, chief executive of a family-owned trucking company, logs onto the Energy Department's Web site and checks the latest average cost of a gallon of diesel fuel. If it is up enough, he raises the charge to haul produ...
articles.abstract: Every Monday morning Dean England, chief executive of a family-owned trucking company, logs onto the Energy Department's Web site and checks the latest average cost of a gallon of diesel fuel. If it is up enough, he raises the charge to haul produce across the country in his tractor-trailers.     A formula has evolved. For every 5-cent rise in the price of fuel, Mr. England's company, C. R. England Inc., based in Salt Lake City, adds 1 percent to its freight rates. Since 2003, those rates are up 37 percent, yet demand has not slackened. The company's 2,800 trucks are constantly on the road.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every Monday morning Dean England, chief executive of a family-owned trucking company, logs onto the Energy Department's Web site and checks the latest average cost of a gallon of diesel fuel. If it is up enough, he raises the charge to haul produce across the country in his tractor-trailers.

articles.headline: Toll Rises in Middle East; Bunker Is Hit
articles.snippet: The deadliest day yet in the deepening two-front Middle East crisis claimed more than 70 lives on Wednesday in Lebanon, the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and northern Israel, with no immediate cease-fire in sight.      ''The country has been torn to s...
articles.abstract: The deadliest day yet in the deepening two-front Middle East crisis claimed more than 70 lives on Wednesday in Lebanon, the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and northern Israel, with no immediate cease-fire in sight.      ''The country has been torn to shreds,'' a desperate Lebanese prime minister, Fouad Siniora, said at a meeting he had called of foreign diplomats, including the American ambassador.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: First Bush Veto Maintains Limits on Stem Cell Use
articles.snippet: President Bush on Wednesday rejected legislation to expand federally supported embryonic stem cell research, exercising his first veto while putting himself at odds with many members of his own party and what polls say is a majority of the public....
articles.abstract: President Bush on Wednesday rejected legislation to expand federally supported embryonic stem cell research, exercising his first veto while putting himself at odds with many members of his own party and what polls say is a majority of the public.     By defying the Republican-controlled Congress, which had sent him legislation that would have overturned research restrictions he imposed five years ago, Mr. Bush re-inserted himself forcefully into a moral, scientific and political debate in which Republicans are increasingly finding common ground with Democrats.

articles.headline: Like Having a Secretary in Your PC
articles.snippet: TESTING, testing, one two three. Is this thing on?      Well, I'll be darned. It's really on and it's really working. I'm wearing a headset, talking, and my PC is writing down everything I say in Microsoft Word. I'm speaking at full speed, perfect...
articles.abstract: TESTING, testing, one two three. Is this thing on?      Well, I'll be darned. It's really on and it's really working. I'm wearing a headset, talking, and my PC is writing down everything I say in Microsoft Word. I'm speaking at full speed, perfectly normally except that I'm pronouncing the punctuation (comma), like this (period).
articles.lead_paragraph: TESTING, testing, one two three. Is this thing on?
